question: What was the remission rate in the Phase 3 trial of Drug X?

source_excerpts.title: Phase 3 Clinical Trial Results for Drug X in Advanced Cancer
source_excerpts.text: The Phase 3 randomized controlled trial of Drug X demonstrated a complete remission rate of 45% in patients with advanced cancer (n=240). The median duration of remission was 18 months, with 95% confidence interval of 14-22 months.

source_excerpts.title: Expert Commentary on Drug X Efficacy
source_excerpts.text: Some experts doubt the generalizability of the 45% remission rate reported in the Phase 3 trial, citing concerns about patient selection criteria and the relatively homogeneous study population.

source_excerpts.title: Long-term Follow-up of Drug X Trial
source_excerpts.text: Updated analysis with 3-year follow-up confirms the initial remission rate findings, though some patients experienced late relapses, reducing the sustained remission rate to approximately 38%.

question: What is the projected sea level rise by 2100 according to IPCC AR6?

source_excerpts.title: IPCC AR6 Working Group I Summary for Policymakers
source_excerpts.text: Under the SSP1-2.6 scenario, global mean sea level is projected to rise by 0.28-0.55 m by 2100. Under SSP5-8.5, the range is 0.63-1.01 m, with a median of 0.82 m.

source_excerpts.title: Recent Ice Sheet Dynamics and Sea Level Projections
source_excerpts.text: New observations of Antarctic ice sheet instability suggest that sea level rise could exceed IPCC projections, potentially reaching 1.5-2.0 m by 2100 under high emission scenarios.

question: What is the energy efficiency of the latest quantum processors?

source_excerpts.title: Quantum Computing Energy Consumption Analysis
source_excerpts.text: Current superconducting quantum processors require approximately 10-50 mW per qubit for operation, though this varies significantly based on architecture and operating conditions.

source_excerpts.title: Comparative Study of Quantum vs Classical Computing Energy
source_excerpts.text: The energy efficiency of quantum processors remains unclear due to limited benchmarking data and the experimental nature of current systems. Estimates range widely from 1-1000 mW per qubit.
